com.gnahraf.io.store.table

Class Table

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.gnahraf.io.store.table.Table
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Closeable, AutoCloseable, Channel
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    SortedTable

    public class Table
extends Object
implements Channel
    A serialized fixed width table supporting random access to its rows. This structure does not delve into defining multiple columns. You can build that yourself; there's only one column in this implementation.

    Concurrent Access

    The underlying FileChannel's position is never modified. Consequently, if the FileChannel's implementation is itself thread-safe, then concurrent reads on an instance of this class are also safe. Not only that, concurrent readers with one append-only writer would also be safe. I say would, because I vaguely recall a while back discovering some crap standard API code that seemed to violate FileChannel's own spec: it would be changing the file position and then setting it back.
    Author:
    Babak

      • filePositionLock

        protected final Object filePositionLock

    • Constructor Detail

      • Table

        public Table(Keystone rowCount,
     FileChannel file,
     long zeroRowFileOffset,
     int rowSize)
      throws IOException
        Creates a new instance by loading an already serialized table. There's no constructor for writing a new empty instance to a file: to write a new instance, you need only write a keystone with value zero, and pass it into this constructor.
        Parameters:
        rowCount - the keystone structure that holds the row count. Usually this keystone is written in the same file in which the table rows are written.
        file - the file channel
        zeroRowFileOffset - the file offset at which the first (zeroth) row starts
        rowSize - the size of each row in bytes (> 0)
        Throws:
        IOException

    • Method Detail

               long count)
                 throws IOException
        Throws:

      • set

        public void set(long row,
       ByteBuffer rowData)
         throws IOException
        Sets the data for the given row.
        Parameters:
        row - the row number (between zero and the row count, inclusive)
        rowData - buffer having 1 or multiple rows of data ready for writing
        Throws:
        IOException

      • append

        public long append(ByteBuffer rowData)
            throws IOException
        Appends one or more rows to the table and returns the index (row number) of the first row appended.
        Parameters:
        rowData - buffer containing data for one or more rows that are to be written. The number of remaining bytes must be a multiple of the row size.
        Throws:
        IOException

      • append

        public long append(ByteBuffer[] rows)
            throws IOException
        Appends one or more rows to the table and returns the index (row number) of the first row appended. Note this method temporarily modifies the file's position
        Parameters:
        rows - non-zero length array of row buffers. The total number of remaining bytes must be an exact, non-zero multiple of the table's rowWidth.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if the rows array is null, or if any of its elements is null
        IllegalArgumentException - if the total number of remaining bytes in the given rows is not a non-zero multiple of the table's rowWidth
        IOException

      • read

        public void read(long row,
        ByteBuffer rowData)
          throws IOException
        Reads a block of one or more rows starting at the given row number.
        Parameters:
        row - the zero-based row number
        rowData - the buffer to which the row data is to be copied to. The number of remaining bytes must be a multiple of the row size.
        Throws:
        IOException

      • transferRows

        public void transferRows(long row,
                long count,
                WritableByteChannel target)
                  throws IOException
        Transfers (copies) a block of rows to the given target. This should be far more efficient than using a secondary work buffer to first read and then write data.
        Parameters:
        row - the starting row number
        count - the number of rows to copy
        target - where the data is copied to
        Throws:
        IOException

      • appendRows

        public void appendRows(Table source,
              long row,
              long count)
                throws IOException
        Appends rows from the given source table. This is likely a lot faster than copying the rows to a buffer and then appending the buffer in this instance.
        Parameters:
        source -
        row - the row number in the source table
        count - the number of rows in the source table to append here
        Throws:
        IOException

      • loadInstance

        public static Table loadInstance(FileChannel file,
                 int rowSize)
                          throws IOException
        Loads and returns a saved instance from the file system.
        Parameters:
        file - the file channel, positioned at the beginning of the table
        rowSize - the byte width of each row
        Throws:
        IOException

      • newSansKeystoneInstance

        public static Table newSansKeystoneInstance(FileChannel file,
                            int rowSize)
                                     throws IOException
        Loads and returns a new or saved instance from the file system. In this type of table there's no keystone structure holding the number of rows in the table: the row count is inferred by the table's byte length. For write-once tables, this is a better choice.
        Parameters:
        file - the file channel, positioned at the beginning of the table
        rowSize - the byte width of each row
        Throws:
        IOException

      • newEmptyInstance

        public static Table newEmptyInstance(FileChannel file,
                     int rowSize)
                              throws IOException
        Creates and returns an empty instance on the file system.
        Parameters:
        file - the file channel, positioned at the beginning of the table
        rowSize - the byte width of each row
        Throws:
        IOException
